title: Managing manure for sustainable livestock production in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed
abstract: M anure presents one of the greatest challenges to livestock (dairy and beef cattle, swine, poultry, equine, sheep, llamas, etc.) operations in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed, serving both as resource and liability. The Chesapeake Bay is threatened by excessive nutrient loadings, and, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA), manure is the source of 18% of the nitrogen and 27% of the phosphorus entering the Chesapeake Bay annually (figure 1) (Chesapeake Bay Program 2010). Developing economical, practical, and effective manure management options for livestock producers will not only contribute to the restoration of the Chesapeake Bay, but will also provide a model for other areas where water quality and livestock production objectives must be balanced. The 166,000 km2 (64,000 mi2) Chesapeake Bay Watershed is home to 3.2 million animal units (animal unit = 454 kg [1,000 lbs] of livestock) generating roughly 36 million t (40 million tn) of livestock manure per year. In comparison, the 14 million humans who call the Chesapeake Bay Watershed home generate 3.6 million t (4 million tn) of waste annually (Brosch 2010; Blankenship 2005). The livestock manure contains approximately 259,000 t (285,000 tn) of nitrogen and 70,000 t (77,000 tn) of phosphorus. Most manure isâ€¦

motivations: Manure from livestock operations poses a significant threat to the Chesapeake Bay Watershed due to excessive nutrient loadings, contributing to water pollution.
Livestock producers in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed lack economical, practical, and effective manure management options, hindering sustainable livestock production.
objectives: Develop and implement effective manure management strategies for livestock producers in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed to mitigate water pollution.
Balance water quality and livestock production objectives in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed, serving as a model for other regions facing similar challenges.
methods: Assess the current manure management practices and their environmental impacts in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.
Develop and evaluate economical and practical manure management options for livestock producers, focusing on nutrient reduction and water quality improvement.
results: Reduce nutrient loadings from manure into the Chesapeake Bay, contributing to its restoration and improved water quality.
Provide livestock producers with effective and sustainable manure management strategies, enhancing the overall sustainability of livestock production in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.
llama_json.research_subject: Sustainable manure management for livestock production in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed

motivations: Manure from livestock operations in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed is a significant source of nutrient pollution, threatening the health of the Chesapeake Bay.
There is a need for economical, practical, and effective manure management options that balance livestock production objectives with water quality.
objectives: Develop effective manure management strategies for livestock producers in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.
Contribute to the restoration of the Chesapeake Bay by reducing nutrient pollution from livestock manure.
Provide a model for balancing water quality and livestock production objectives in other areas.
methods: Study the impact of livestock manure on nutrient loadings in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.
Develop and test practical and economical manure management strategies for livestock producers.
results: Reduce the nutrient pollution in the Chesapeake Bay caused by livestock manure.
Improve the sustainability of livestock production in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.
Provide a model for sustainable livestock production in other regions with similar challenges.
openai_json.research_subject: Sustainable manure management in livestock production in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed

motivations: Manure from livestock operations contributes 18% of nitrogen and 27% of phosphorus entering the Chesapeake Bay, threatening water quality through excessive nutrient loadings.
Livestock producers need economical and practical manure management solutions that balance agricultural production with environmental protection.
objectives: Develop economical, practical, and effective manure management options for livestock producers in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed.
Create a model for balancing water quality objectives with livestock production that can be applied to other regions facing similar challenges.
results: Contribute to the restoration of the Chesapeake Bay through improved manure management practices.
Provide a replicable model for other regions to balance water quality and livestock production objectives.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Sustainable manure management for livestock production in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed
